61875121
>>61875077
It isn’t strictly tied to the dollar. It WAS before 2005, but now it’s a managed float system that is managed by the central bank. The dollar plays a big role, but it isn’t as if the yuan keeps strict pace with the dollar. They can (and do) manage its exchange rate. Exactly how they determine what the exchange rate should be is the opaque part. One way they manage the yuan’s value is by buying/selling dollars with their currency, and this is one reason why the keep so many dollars in reserve.

This is also why, earlier in the thread, I argued that the dollar’s role as a reference point for a currency can still cause it to be accumulated.

61875124
>>61872964
Sour fucking grapes. The Jews running the west are such idiots

61875149
>>61875074
Germans don't even believe in debt, they had a rule in their constitution that they couldn't borrow more than 0.35% of GDP annually until 2025 when shit hit the fan for needing to build a real military.
>Reee we aren't taking on debt so you can't either reeee

61875160
>>61873120
They’re disgusting gook bugmen that are not human

61875205
>>61874965
A currency cannot be "undervalued", because there is no "fair" or "inherent" value for a currency.

China keeps its currency stable relative to other currencies, mainly USD, to avoid currency exchange risk for exporting and importing companies.

China has a ridiculous surplus because (a) Chinese companies are ridiculously competitive, (b) Chinese companies are not allowed to import the kind of things they want to import because of export controls, (c) Chinese companies are afraid an over-dependence on imports will lead to them being rug-pulled by new export controls or piracy, and (d) the CPC has a "minimize China's dependence on others, maximize others' dependence on China" philosophy on how to win trade wars and avoid shooting wars.

61875302
>>61875205
Just because there isn’t an underlying physical commodity to back the currency doesn’t mean that the currency can’t still be undervalued (or overvalued). Parity for currencies, even currencies in a fiat system, is one way that this is calculated.

If a basket of various goods in the US goes for 100 dollars and that same basket of goods in Vietnam goes for 10 dollars (ALL ELSE BEING EQUAL), then a fair exchange rate would be 10 dong for one dollar. This is one way that these are calculated—people look at prices for similar goods, adjust for import and other costs, and determine how much that currency can actually purchase. When a country sets their own exchange rate, even if partially like in china’s case, it’s possible to undervalue it. They have an incentive to claim that their currency is weaker than it actually is.

So, no, that simply isn’t true. I know what you’re trying to say—fiat money has no intrinsic value—but it doesn’t mean that it can’t be undervalued or overvalued relative to other currencies. There’s a reason why economists or even someone casually interested in the economy and trade policy use these terms.

>>61875149

61875554
>>61875121

61875563
>>61875517
Well, my point was that by managing the currency in order to keep it low, it makes exports more attractive, which results in a huge surplus. If the yuan floated freely, this would eventually correct. A huge trade surplus would mean more demand for the yuan and it would strengthen the currency. However, China doesn’t let this happen. If the currency strengthens or threatens to strengthen beyond what they deem desirable, they weaken their currency by selling yuan or by setting a lower daily exchange rate. This is the advantage of a managed currency, but it also means that it pisses everyone off when their own exports aren’t as competitive or their domestic industries suffer. China claims that they don’t this to the extent that they’re accused of, and it definitely comes in waves of egregiousness, but it seems like they’re back at it.

So yeah, it’s true they’re good at exporting, but their insane trade surplus is in part the result of what I’m describing (an undervalued yuan that is kept undervalued by china’s central bank).

It can be undervalued and tied to the dollar. Read my post. You seem to think that because a currency’s exchange rate hasn’t changed that it can’t be undervalued or overvalued. That’s not true. Its real value in terms of purchasing power could rise and the central bank could artificially exert downward pressure (which would mean that the exchange rate would stay roughly the same over time). This is exactly what China has been accused of forever, and the issue is that China issue exactly forthcoming with their economic data.

It is obviously tied to the dollar. It is not STRICTLY PEGGED to the dollar. Every day the PBOC sets the exchange rate. The argument is that this rate hasn’t changed and has remained too low for how much demand there is for the yuan.

item.title: Would you have done the same? — 14 replies — 36.9/hr
item.content:encoded:
Would you have done the same?

Open thread • Replies: 14 • Updated: 2026-02-20 04:06 UTC

OP

I am a nurse at a large hospital's psych unit. I am also a newly graduated psychiatric nurse practitioner. I was about to start an NP job with a guaranteed salary of 150k with good benefits and a decent RVU bonus (bonuses for how many patients I see). However, this job has incredibly shady business practices, terrible reviews from former employees and was far away from home. The job was in a northern suburb of Dallas-Fort Worth, Texas. It was three 12 hour shifts in a row without a lunch break. I was supposed to start in early April.

I resigned last night in favor of a job close to family in a rural area in the southeast USA. This job pays me a 6,000$ a month draw and 67% of my collections. After I pay off the draw in a few months I could make as much money as I want, but that is contingent on the amount of patients I see. I can work as much or as little as I want. Take as much lunch break as I want. Benefits are offered W-2, but the health insurance is expensive. Here I will be doing real psychiatry and not corporate slop crap psychiatry. Also, my family is very happy about me staying close to home.

Basically I am trading certain money at a shit job for uncertain money (albeit a higher ceiling) at a good job. I talked to one of the NPs at the new place and he says that he makes about 24,000$ a month before taxes after working for 5 years. This would be almost double what I would have made in Frisco.

Do you think I made the right choice? Would you have done the same?

Also, If I somehow get fired while still paying the draw I have to pay it all off in 10 days, which would be nightmare scenario. There is more risk with the good job.

>US market has had a good run for about 15 years, but that doesn't mean it will continue to. Foreign stocks are beating the everloving fuck out of US stocks this year so for for example.
that's why he said global ETF

honestly abusing correlation seems only worth it if the assets have an equal return to stocks, all this junk has such low return even if its negatively correlated you're not going to get a free reduction in variance with it without killing your return. That's why i heard some paper showed its optimal to just go 100% stocks. Even if your a boomer, bonds aren't really worth it, you can just adjust your spending if theres a downturn and still come out ahead.

Trying to finds stocks/etfs that are weakly correlated seems to be the play.

>>61872888

61873222

61873231
>>61873220
You accept more risk (volatility) for those higher returns, that's the tradeoff. If you are OK with higher risk then you could always choose one of those balanced allocation funds.

AOR for example just rebalances a 60% stock / 40% bond index portfolio.

AOA does the same thing but 80% stock (more risk)

These really are the easy button for people that don't want to self-manage imo.

Probably a good idea to put the portion that's your emergency fund into something boring and very lowvol but decent yield. Check out JPST, that might be a good fit.

>>61873477
>>61873686
Maybe someday, not right now. For what >>61873827 said and because it just sucks at answering niche or complex questions. When I ask it things it usually feeds me flat out wrong answers that would be passable to someone that didn't do any research.

One example is having it try to pick stocks. Gets obliterated by the index funds every time. It's a consistent loser at this because it can't make forward projections and the question is too complicated for it. Tax questions are a horror show too, you'd think it would be good at those.

The main issue with AI in my eyes is that it just doesn't understand humans/human nature. Most of my job is behavioral.

>>61873887
I do, I made a bunch of money in it 2016ish and now build and rebalance a position in my retirement accounts (5-10% allocation).

61874061
>>61874040
Wish I knew more about EU investing, I'm completely specialized for US investing so it's out of my wheelhouse. I only have a handful of expat/foreign clients.

EU bonds have been zero or even negative for a long time. I won't touch them because they don't compensate you for loaning them money, and I can't believe people keep buying them.

Apparently it has something to do with their SIPC insurance equivalent, safer park for cash than a checking account basically because of the federal coverage you get by buying a bond. I haven't looked much into it just what I heard.

61874087
>>61873887
>does your firm/company advise on it?

Forgot to answer this part. We don't buy it in our portfolios, but we do help clients manage the risk associated with it. Some people are believers in crypto so we highlight the risks (volatility, no intrinsic value, etc) and then work with them to figure out how much of their overall investments is a prudent amount to put into that risk asset. I personally cap myself at 10% for both gold and crypto.

Crypto is actually considered speculation instead of investing by most managers. Kind of like commodities/gold/NFTs.

61874261
>>61873448
>its still not beating the stock market
It does in the 26-year backward looking period in the data array from the picture by 30bp. Instead of just pulling 7% out of your booty you could spend 10 seconds doing the present value calculation if you really wanted.


It's about 9.8% annualized if you go all the way back to '71 from now ($39-$5,000). That's definitely nothing to scoff at when constructing a portfolio and hedging equity markets considering the 0.1 correlation.

>That is insane volatility
Volatility is good in a portfolio of non-correlated assets that's rebalanced outside of tolerance bands.

>all that volatility it still doesn't match the market
Almost keeps up with it and doesn't move in the same direction, which is the idea. Non-correlated assets, rebalancing the volatility, and risk-return tradeoff are portfolio construction 101.

61874286
Alright anon, I'm out. Have a great day and I hope every one of you gets to retire early.

PS long nursing homes

61874295
>>61872433
Is there a gap in the asset management & financial planning software market? Seems you are just using an excel sheet there. Is there any way your life could be easier or more automated?

I'm a developer and I like money

61874345
>>61874295
The software is pretty comprehensive and generally way deeper than just an excel sheet, but of course there's an industry spectrum of how deep/detailed the analysis goes by firm and by program.

Some is straight up basically a cash flows projection laid on top of a balance sheet (excel). The people that use this are shitty whole life insurance people.

It's the auxiliary software where the money is at right now it seems. AI that reads trusts using OCR and spits out a summary to help you find issues. Tax software. Stuff like that.

Our software for portfolio management (have used 3) is AWFUL though. That's a big gap for asset management imho.

61876336
>>61874261
Im sorry but your sample size is not big enough. The volatility and nature of the distribution of gold prices (its not normally distributed) means you have to be very careful about inferring information about long term returns. For example if you look at gold as an asset just 5 years ago you get very different conclusions.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ulgqlQWlPbo If the data changes heavily based on the precise dates or periods that you choose it indicates it hasn't converged to an acceptable error margin yet. 7% is a guess at what an average random sample period would be given that they can range from ~3% to ~9% or w/e but idk, im not gonna do your job for you.

A simple sanity check should tell you that an asset that doesn't produce or do much of anything shouldn't outperform real cash generating businesses and companies in the long term.
